overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students sketch graphs of transformed quadratic functions, compare characteristics of the transformed graphs with those of the graph of the basic function and write the transformations using coordinate notation. Students write quadratic equations in vertex form using the coordinates of the vertex and another point on the graph and in factored form using the zeros and another point on the graph.

overview_item_data_items: I can recognize the key characteristics revealed by different forms of a quadratic function.
I can write the equation of a transformed quadratic function based on a graph or a description of its features.
I can translate, reflect, and dilate quadratic functions horizontally and vertically.
I can describe how changes to a quadratic function's equation affect its graph.
I can use coordinate notation to describe transformations.
I can identify the values in a quadratic equation that determine how the graph is transformed.
Choose and produce an equivalent form of an expression to reveal and explain properties of the quantity represented by the expression.
Factor a quadratic expression to reveal the zeros of the function it defines.

Rearrange formulas to highlight a quantity of interest, using the same reasoning as in solving equations. For example, rearrange Ohm's law <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>I</mi><mi>R</mi></math> to highlight resistance <math><mi>R</mi></math>.
Identify the effect on the graph of replacing <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy=

>)</mo></math> for specific values of <math><mi>k</mi></math> (both positive and negative); find the value of <math><mi>k</mi></math> given the graphs. Experiment with cases and illustrate an explanation of the effects on the graph using technology. Include recognizing even and odd functions from their graphs and algebraic expressions for them.

The vertex form for a quadratic function is <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy=
>)</mo></math> is the location of the vertex and the sign of <math><mi>a</mi></math> indicates whether the parabola opens upward or downward.
A function written in equivalent forms can reveal different characteristics of the function it defines.
You can write a quadratic function in vertex form when you know the coordinates of the vertex and another point on the graph.
You can write a quadratic function in factored form when you know the zeros and another point on the graph.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students compare the graph of an absolute value function and a quadratic function.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Translations and Reflections of Quadratic Functions
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students investigate vertical and horizontal translations and reflections of the basic quadratic function.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Vertical and Horizontal Dilations of Quadratic Functions
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students investigate vertical or horizontal dilations of the basic quadratic function.
Students describe how the graph of each transformed function compares to the graph of <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy=

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Using Reference Points to Graph Quadratic Functions
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students use reference points and transformations to graph quadratic functions.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Vertex Form of a Quadratic Function
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students investigate the vertex form of quadratic equations.
Use what you know about the transformation function form to answer each question.

overview_item_data_items: If facilitating this lesson without student devices, no additional materials are needed.
To avoid printing additional materials not included in MATHbook (like Activate activities and Session Quick Checks) project them using the Present button above.
